"Roommate" has different meanings in the US and the UK.
We can also use "rent" in different ways: as a verb ("to rent"); as a noun ("the rent"); and as an adjective ("rented"). Have a look at the examples below.
Is this your place?
Do you want to come to my place for dinner?

The meaning becomes stronger.

Let’s talk some more about moving house! We've talked about the difference between renting and owning a place. The person who owns a house is the “owner”. If they rent it out, they’re a "landlord" (for men) or a "landlady" (for women). The person who rents a place is a "tenant". If you live in a flatshare, the people who share the flat with you are your "flatmates" or "roommates".
rent
Have you [h]put[/h] [h]down[/h] a deposit yet?
pay
What is happening in the dialogue?
[h]My[/h] [h]friends[/h] are renting their spare rooms out.
The landlord doesn't allow pets in the flat.
Complete the sentence with the British English version of "apartment".
We like the flat. I think we're [k]going[/k] [k]to put down[/k] a deposit.
This means that someone will pay David £400 per month to rent his spare room.
I [k]put down[/k] the deposit yesterday, and I have to go and sign the contract today.
a tenant
they + to put down (past simple tense)
They [h]rent[/h] their spare rooms [h]out[/h] to students
meet her new flatmates.
We've seen some more phrasal verbs in this lesson. In this unit, we'll review word order and how to conjugate phrasal verbs. Here are the verbs we'll use in this unit.
a flat on her own.
Adjective: I am looking for some rented accommodation.
I need to go to the estate agents and sign the contract.
Past simple: They put their house up for sale.
I have a new roommate!
Select the words that form the verb in this sentence.
I moved into a flatshare with three other students last week. We rent it from an estate agents. When I finish university I would like to buy a house in the countryside.
to hand over (past simple tense)
Present perfect: They have put their house up for sale.
If you rent the place where you live you are...
After they saw the house, [k]they put down[/k] a deposit.
I'm still looking for some [k]rented[/k] accommodation. I would love to live in a [k]studio[/k], but they are so expensive!
If I found a new flat sooner, I [k]would move out|'d move out[/k] earlier.
We [k]are putting[/k] down a deposit on a house.
As we know, this doesn't always work. There are some phrasal verbs that always remain together. In this lesson, these are:
we're
Complete the sentence using the information in the box.
Sure!
Select the words that form the object of this sentence.
I used to live in a [k]flatshare[/k] in that [k]block[/k] when I was a student.

Usually, a flat (or apartment) will be part of a block of flats (or apartment block) or a housing estate. People often rent one bedroom in a flat. When different people rent rooms in a shared flat / apartment, we call it a "flatshare". Flatshares are usually the cheapest type of accommodation.
Did you notice? In order to use a phrasal verb in different tenses, we only need to conjugate the base verb. The following word (the preposition) does not change. Easy!
apartment
Click on the words that refer to types of accommodation.
to put up
We finally got the keys to our new home!
We [k]own[/k] it, do you like it?
nice and big.
Sara owns the place she lives in.
What usually happens to the meaning of the base verb when we add the preposition?
I need to go to the estate agents and [k]sign the contract[/k].
Select the words in the correct order.
Which of these sentences is in the past continuous tense?

When we have found accommodation to rent, we usually need to "put down a deposit" and "sign the contract". We can do this with a private landlord or with an "estate agent", a business which manages properties. When we have signed the contract, we "get the keys" to the flat / house and we are ready to "move in"!
Verb: I am viewing an apartment in the afternoon.
put down
Before she gets the keys Claire has to...

Select the correct words to fill the gaps.

He was renting out his spare room.
Present continous: They are putting their house up for sale.
Memorise the word(s).
David is telling Sara about his new flat.
I am viewing an [h]apartment[/h] in the afternoon.
less expensive than a studio.
Another good verb to know is the verb "to let". The landlord lets a property, while the tenants rent the property from the landlord. The verb "to rent out" is a synonym of "to let".
The [k]landlord|owner|landlady[/k] doesn't allow pets in the flat.
Verb: Are you renting this place?
Match the word with its translation.
A document you sign before renting a property.
I would love to live in a studio, but the rent is so expensive in London!
Oh, so you haven't [k]moved[/k] in yet?
No, I'll get the keys once I [k]sign the contract[/k].
[k]Are[/k] you [k]going to move in[/k] with your friend in Berlin?
I am [k]viewing[/k] an apartment in the afternoon, would you like to come with me?
What is a phrasal verb?
We were [k]renting[/k] out our spare room to a student.
He rented out his spare room.
What is the object in the sentence: "We're going to put down a deposit."?
Claire hasn't met the people she will live with.
Yes, he's very friendly. I haven't met my new [k]flatmates[/k] yet though!
Conditional: They would put their house up for sale.
[k]This[/k] [k]housing[/k] [k]estate[/k] [k]was probably[/k] [k]built[/k] [k]in the[/k] [k]70s.[/k]
the landlady
will move out
to move out (second conditional form)

contract
A person who lives in a rented property.
the most expensive accommodation.
Will is moving house with Claire.

to hand over
With some phrasal verbs, we can move the object in between the two words which form the verb.
I moved into the house.
The meaning stays the same.
rented
David and Sara are talking about accommodation.
Laura is looking for some short-term rented accommodation in Naples.
put the flat up
Usually, before we buy or rent accommodation, we visit it. This is called a "viewing". You can use this expression as a verb (to view) or as a noun (a viewing). Have a look at the examples below.
down
rented
Yeah, I'm actually [k]viewing[/k] an apartment in the afternoon, would you like to come with me?
rent out
A sum of money you pay before renting a property.
Is this your place?
William
accommodation
We finally [k]got the keys[/k] to our new home!

In this unit, we are going to talk about accommodation. We'll learn some more words and phrases that we can use to describe where we live. You probably already know the words "flat" and "house". In English, it's also common to use the word  "place" to talk about your flat / house.
In the UK, a roommate shares your room with you. In the US it has a similar meaning to "housemate" / “flatmate”.
Listen to the dialogue. Is this statement true?
The meaning changes.

A flat and an apartment are the same thing. We usually say "flat" in British English, and "apartment" in American and Canadian English, but both words are understood in both countries.
Listen to the dialogue. Is this statement true?

Let's look again at word order. As you know, the structure of a basic English sentence is subject + verb + object.

In this section we're going to learn how to conjugate phrasal verbs (in other words, learn how to form phrasal verbs in different tenses). It's quite simple. Can you identify the conjugated phrasal verbs in the following exercises?
Do you own this place or are you renting it?
house
